input:
What brings you in today?**PATIENT CHARACTER:** Patient with Non-syndromic genetically-determined hypermelanosis or lentiginosis

ROLEPLAY SCRIPT:
YOU ARE A PATIENT: YOU ARE A 45-YEAR-OLD WOMAN
You are experiencing the following symptoms:
- Multiple small, brown to dark brown macules (lentigines) spread across your face, hands, and arms
- Increased pigmentation in areas that were previously lighter, especially on your cheeks and shoulders
- Presence of a few slightly raised skin lesions that look different from the surrounding skin
- A family history of similar skin pigmentation and skin cancer in your mother and grandfather
These symptoms came into fruition gradually over the past three years, with the lentigines becoming more numerous and prominent over time. You first noticed the pigmentation changes on your face and hands about three years ago, but they have slowly expanded and become more noticeable. You are concerned because your family has a history of skin issues and you're worried about the possibility of skin cancer, especially given your fair skin and significant sun exposure over the years.

ANSWER: Well, I’m 45, and I’m a woman, and I’ve noticed these little brown spots popping up all over my face, hands, and arms. They’ve been there for about three years, but they seem to be getting worse and more noticeable. Some of the skin also looks darker in a few places, and I have a couple of spots that look a little different, raised even. My mom and grandfather had similar stuff, and they also had skin cancer, so I keep worrying that this might be serious. I feel really anxious about what it could be and if I’m at risk.
